ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The ability to critically evaluate scientific publications on ecology and ecosystem functioning, and think in terms of a complex adaptive system. The capacity to deliver a management plan towards a given set of goals and understand certain shortcomings of prevalent environmental arguments.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I cannot think of any better way that I could have been taught on these concepts. Os and Mark did a fantastic job on using scientific literature and a fully interdisciplinary approach to engage us in discussions, direct us through the assignments aimed to apply the concepts. A weakness may be the organization of lab sessions, but I guess the logistics was embedded in the mixture of undergrads and grad students in the same class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This course is heavily front loaded and can be demanding towards the middle of the semester. However, the rewards of the class and the way of thinking it develops helps the understanding of environmental issues.

its an okay course but assumes a great deal of knowledge, and is not super well organized--most of the work is based on a group project and the amount you get out of this entirely depends on your TA--ours was terrible and we learned very little.
